positive.review:
My experience so far in Guild Wars 2. 

Guild Wars can be overwhelming once you hit level 80 but if you pick a couple of goals to work towards its actually quite refreshing. There is no gear treadmill in Guild Wars which effectively allows players the freedom of doing whatever activity they actually enjoy doing without pressure to "gear up". I felt a FOMO a total of ZERO times so far in the X hours I've played. There is no RUSH to end game like other certain games in the same genre. The end game is pick your poison.  

One of the biggest draws to the game for me is the open world in particular - meta events. These events attract a large amount of players all committed towards a common goal, usually a boss.  The open world content is top shelf to say the least which attributes to the game feeling very much "alive". That's just one of the many elements of Guild Wars 2 that players can participate in, there are also fractals ( mini dungeons ), Raids, Strikes, PVP, World V World, World Bosses, Mount collection, Achievment hunting and legendary gear crafting to name a few. I probably missed some stuff. 

Some things to note: 

- This is not a theme park MMORPG, meaning all the old expansions and zones are still active and have players running around doing all sorts of things. Old content = still relevant. 

- If you don't like the story then getting through the MSQ can be a drag. With unskippable dialogue it can be an absolute ball drag at times.

- You can play for free but also remember as F2P you are gated out of a tremendous amount of content which they have strategically placed behind, imo, fair pay walls. Keep a look out for sales. 

- Is Guild Wars Pay to Win? 
No, but it is pay for convenience, as you can buy gold directly from the cash shop.  

- The GW2 wiki is your friend.

- There is no subscription fee. 

- Get yourself a good mount as one of your first priorities ( I got Skyscale ). It is a necesary quality of life improvement that will impact your whole playing experience. I'm constantly saying to myself " Thank *&^% I've got Skyscale."

Thanks for reading,

Been playing GW2 for about 8 years, 5 on the ANet client, now on Steam and it‚Äôs still the most well-rounded MMO I‚Äôve ever played.

What keeps me here is the freedom. There‚Äôs always something to do. I can chill with world events, jump into PvP or WvW, or just wander and enjoy the atmosphere. The community‚Äôs very supportive, the game never forces a grind, and it always feels rewarding whether I play for 30 minutes or 3 hours.

GW2 isn‚Äôt just content, it‚Äôs a world that still feels alive every time I log in

The only thing I do not like about this game is that you have to certain achievements to complete items. I dislike PvP and WvW, yet you are forced to play in order to get items for crafting. There should be alternative means to get these items for crafting if pvping is not your thing. These items should be available for pve through meta events. Just my opinion.

as someone who comes from WOW i have to say the questing is quite fun, the game allows you to explore on your own accord while also giving you direction to whats closest to you. main story missions are check pointed after every 10 levels so if you complete the main story fast you are forced to explore the word, do world events and make relations with key npcs for EXP. this is by far the best aspect of the game for me. it really allows me to explore the ins and outs of the map and be rewarded for it. as opposed to accepting a quests from random npcs you dont know or realy care about. i am still in this early leveling stages only at level 62 for my 3rd day in, but the leveling stage is important for a new player and the game so far has kept me entertained.

Runs and feels better polished than most MMORPG's on the market right now. Even without exitlag.

A plus is the Spanish translation which is almost 95% correct so it helps people on South America.
Very good MMO, Community is super friendly and now i can finally  play on steam with -provider Portal and its so fun on the on the steamdeck!

Having logged over 3000 hours on my main (non-steam) account thus far I would have to say that Guild Wars has been a boon and a curse over the past 10+ years. Here is the recap:

First off I was delighted when it got released on Steam as well - a second wind for the game and a new playerbase able to visit tyria (& experience the wonderful soundtrack - kudos to the composers!)

Investment 1: From a money perspective -> well-spent. No subscription. Buy the base game+add-ons and you get hundreds of hours of content. Want to take a break? No problem, return in a few months and you will see many improvements (without paying a dime during the time you were gone - devs are doing a good job in that regard)

The map design has overall always been very nice and I really appreciate the paint-brush aesthetics utilized in all parts of the game. The concepts and artwork in general is beautiful (look it up online)

As with many MMORPGS, it distracts you just fine from the everyday stressors of life. Maybe too much at times. Or it stresses you in other ways. If I am tired of chores in real life, Guild Wars presents me with new chores and new to do lists... makes you finish collections, achievements of all kinds & play the story chapters more often than you want to (depending on the expansion, even playing it once could be considered one too many). At least the underlying lore was always interesting. 


The end-game. Well... instead of buying new clothes in real life, you hunt for skins in the game. 'Fashion Wars'. Also, instead of going to the convenience store you play 'Convenience Wars' and pay hundreds of gold for things just to have them easily available on all the other characters as well (even if you hardly play them, you start to 'need it, just in case..'). So you keep grinding... for things you wanted yesterday, or things you might want to want at some point... which brings me to:

Investment 2: From a time-perspective -> your results may vary. I know of guys who study the (trading) market and have excel sheets - this is where I draw the line. I already have an office job.


9/10 escape reality wars, 9/10 fashion wars, 8/10 sunk cost fallacy wars, 5/10 story wars, 10/10 soundtrack wars
Averaging at 8.2 - so. yeah. recommended

9/10 [‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê - ]
--------------
Leave WoW and blizzard behind and come join a game that actually respects your time and wallet.  
The game is VERY active with a world full of people and events, no way near behind dead in any aspect. 
--------------
üó∫Ô∏è A World That Actually Feels Alive
Tyria is one of those rare MMO worlds where you don‚Äôt feel like the chosen errand-runner following glowing exclamation marks. You walk into a zone and the zone is already doing stuff: villages getting attacked, NPCs fighting back, massive bosses spawning, random players rallying together. The world doesn‚Äôt wait for you ‚Äî you join it. And that makes exploration insanely satisfying.

‚öîÔ∏è Combat That‚Äôs Fast, Fluid, and Fun
This isn‚Äôt tab-target snooze-fest combat. GW2‚Äôs fights feel active: dodging matters, positioning matters, combo fields make you feel smart, and every class has real personality. Switching builds and elite specs can completely change how the game feels, so experimenting stays exciting even after hundreds of hours.

üéØ Dynamic Events > Quest Checklists
Instead of ‚Äúkill 10 boars,‚Äù you get dynamic events that spiral into full-on map-wide moments. An escort turns into a siege, which turns into a boss fight, which turns into a celebration with loot raining everywhere. It creates natural momentum and makes the game feel like an adventure instead of a to-do list.

üß≠ Progression That Respects Your Time
No sub fee. No endless gear treadmill. You don‚Äôt get invalidated every expansion. GW2 leans into horizontal progression: mastery systems, mounts, new ways to play, quality-of-life unlocks, cosmetics, builds. You can step away for a month and come back without feeling punished. That alone makes it stand out.

ü§ù A Community Built for Cooperation
The game is designed so helping others feels normal, not like you‚Äôre losing efficiency. Shared loot, open tagging, easy revives, big metas where everyone benefits ‚Äî it naturally pushes players to work together. And it shows. World bosses and map metas often feel like friendly chaos in the best way.

üìñ Expansions That Keep Getting Better
Each expansion doesn‚Äôt just add content ‚Äî it adds game-changing systems. Gliding, mounts with unique movement mechanics, elite specs that reinvent classes, gorgeous maps, and some of the most cinematic MMO encounters out there. The game keeps evolving instead of repeating itself.

üé® Fashion Wars Is Real Endgame
Calling it a meme is unfair. The customization here is wild: dyes, skins, gliders, mounts, legendaries, outfits ‚Äî and because gear power doesn‚Äôt reset every patch, looking cool becomes a real long-term goal that‚Äôs actually fun to chase.

‚úÖ Pros

Gorgeous, living world that rewards exploration

Best-in-class dynamic event system

Combat feels modern, responsive, and flexible

No subscription + chill progression model

Friendly, cooperative community

Expansions add meaningful new gameplay

‚ùå Cons

You may accidentally play for 6 hours ‚Äújust doing one more event‚Äù

Inventory management can get spicy if you hoard everything (guilty)

The game is so packed with systems it can feel overwhelming at first

üèÅ Verdict
GW2 is the kind of MMO that makes you log in because you‚Äôre excited, not because you‚Äôre behind. It‚Äôs epic without being exhausting, social without being stressful, and full of moments that feel genuinely alive.

If you like exploration, action combat, big co-op battles, or just want an MMO that respects your time: play this. ‚úÖ

Guild Wars 2 is above and beyond my favorite video game that I have played for thousands upon thousands of hours across multiple accounts since 2012. This game provides so many different opportunities for people to enjoy the game in a wide variety of different ways. From a more casual open world adventure to more intense team centric competitive content and everything in between. 

You can play most of the game by yourself should you choose with the easy ability to casually begin playing with others and joining in on any activity taking place across the world. But should you decide that you want to become more social and play with lots of people, the opportunity is there as Guild Wars 2 has a massive community with so many different people playing it and many smaller communities built within the game.

This game has so much content from the original launch of the game and the large amount of updates and expansions that followed afterwards. While I have played for such a long time, there is still constantly more that I can do. Anybody who enjoys playing through a content rich game would definitely enjoy diving deep into Guild Wars 2 just because of how much quality content there is. And this may seem overwhelming for many people, but the game is incredibly simple and easy to get into and you should you decide you want to dive deeper... you can.

This is the MMO that pioneered what it means to be a modern MMO, and by that I mean a MMO in the post WoW world.  The ability to dodge, use cover, move around, use skill combos in real time makes combat fast pace and fun.  There is a high skill cap for this game, which makes it different from most other MMOs. But its also one of the few MMOs where you are encouraged to work together with whoever is running around in the open world.  Most of the best moments i have had in this game have come from joint meta events across Tyria. Add the wide range of gear, leveling, skills, classes (and sub classes).  Theres so much there to keep a average and even a hardcore fan going for thousands of hours. 

Go enjoy the free version for a bit, then do yourself a favor and buy the full version.

This is a Goated MMORPG. No sub required and all content stays relevant (and populated!) throughout expansions.
Don't expect a WoW clone. GW2 makes its own path through the genre.

The good (incoming wall):
No empty zones
Big PVE and PVP scene
Life-like mounts
Fun combat with toggle between tab-targeting and action camera
Build versatility
No pressure to do certain activities
Customisable dailies
Friendly community
No in-your-face cash shop popups
MTX is cosmetic and QoL
Can convert in-game gold to MTX currency
F2P model is more than fair
Crafting is actually useful
Jump in any expansion at level cap
Can be as casual or hardcore as you make it
Try out full builds and elite specs in the PVP lobby from level 1

The bad:
Addictive
Loot management
Some older story content can feel a bit clunky/unpolished but not enough to be a deal breaker

The different:
Some systems take a bit of getting used to, but once it clicks you're golden

Steam or ANet?
ANet 100% - Some bundles are only available there, plus gifted MTX currency cannot be used through Steam account, among others

tl;dr
Go play it!

I've tried this game a few time and quit every time. The problem is, changing mmo's is like a break up. I needed some time between my few year journey through with another mmo to really appreciate this one. 

With that being said, this game is dope. 

To start its completely free to try and no monthly subscription, so worst case your'e only missing out on 
the time invested in the download if you really hate it. 

The diversity in this game is crazy with many different play styles being perfectly viable. The world around you feels alive, npc dialogue, random events, large meta events, instanced content, challenge modes etc.

The devs respect your time. This game is perfect for someone that cant sink tons of hours into a game to stay competitive. The gear/loot hamster wheel that many games rely on to keep you coming back is non existant. Once you earn good gear, you have good gear. 

There is no pay to win. You can pay for convenience or cosmetics but its not required to enjoy the game. 

The community in my experience has been nothing but pleasant with literally one or two exceptions here or there. Overall everyone has been helpful. Some so much so as to group up with me one on one and answer any and all questions i had in the game.

TLDR: Hit the download button and give it a fair shot with an open mind, ( Its literally free ) This game does things different and comparing it to another mmo does everyone a disservice.

I don't play this on steam I play on the actual client, but just wanted to say I really enjoy how laid back this mmorpg is. There's no rush to gear up get to end game. You just login when you feel like it and explore.

To call this game an MMO does it a bit of a disservice. This game is every bit as fun and rewarding as any singleplayer game. You just get a ton more game for your money(Free).

The sense of wonder and adventure you can get from this game is the best in the genre. The zone maps are dense and packed with fun content. The story is engaging and respects your decisions, and the world feels alive. The exploration and sense of discovery is incredible. 

The 9 Classes offer a ton of replayability, and can be tweaked endlessly to suit your playstyle. It's not just a meme. You can play a warrior who shouts at his friends to make them feel better, and with a few adjustments make him a conquering hero who plants battle standards that break enemy morale and help turn the tide of battles.

My absolute favorite thing about this game is how well it treats roleplayers. Every non-story quest is handled in a way that lets you tackle one objective multiple ways. So if your character is more of a pacifist there is a method that lets you complete a quest(Known in this game as a "renown heart".) that is catered to that playstyle. While all classes are designed for combat, there are still ways to get things done without ever killing an enemy. This can make for difficult leveling challenges, like playing the game with only crafted items, or leveling to 80 without killing a single enemy.

Another big part of my enjoyment comes from the exploration and zone design. There's the adage "If there is a chest behind that waterfall the game is good." and it really sings here. Every map is multifaceted and littered with "moments" of exploration. From underwater cities where orca people live, to following a cliffside to a vista collectable that earns you a nice chunk of experience, to swimming into a small barely noticeable hole in a lake bed and finding yourself parkouring a bomb through a griffon nesting ground to explode a chest at the end.  Every map in the game has at least one big secret that isn't even remotely hinted at and gathering everything is super satisfying. There is even a tracker that takes stock of all of the collectibles on a map and rewards you handsomely for finding and completing everything.

This is a super basic primer of the content that is just in the base game, I have not even played the expansions yet. This is just the core base game experience.(It's a free game btw.)

i'm fairly early on in the game, I have a bad tendency to make a character play for a bit, quit then come back delete my old character and start fresh.

So I'll spare you the details and tell you what sets it apart from other MMO's.
- Base game is free, give it a try and see how you feel. The only thing you'll lose is your time and storage space.
- The style is phenomenal with a painterly look to it. It is showing it's age now a days but what's underneath is what's important.
- What's underneath is a great action combat MMO akin to Tera [rip] and a lot of polish on the core mechanics.
- Big open world boss events, even in 'starter' areas.
- Race choice puts you into a multi hour zone where your backstory affects the narrative, more involved than even OG WoW.
- Buy once, subscribe never. Insane business model, but the mad lads have done it somehow.
- Jump puzzles and random events keep things interesting. 
- Classes have so much diversity, changing weapons changes skills, then you have specs which can be multi classed with other skill trees.
- Permanent progression. Practically the holy grail of MMO's, off the top of my head only runescape and adventure quest do this. You can leave your character and not play for years, come back and you'll be right where you left off and not behind the curve at all. A stark contrast to modern MMO's like wow where you miss the first few months and you're rushing to catch up or give up entirely until the next patch 5 months later. 
- Mount movement so great that Blizzard stole it. 

The core idea behind this game and why people love it so much is how fair to the player it is and how despite not playing for long periods of time it's always there just waiting for you to come back and doesnt punish you for being away. The focus on horizontal progression where it's discovering things, doing jumping puzzles, fighting world bosses completely sets it apart from games that have a loot chase scene like wow. 

As gamers we all know that we grind for months to get gear to do big numbers and then the mmo company rip it away from us, only to bump it progressively higher until they cant anymore. Then they squish everything down and repeat. This just feels bad. Guild Wars 2 has been drip feeding me gear, but it feels impactful on my character and I can rest easy knowing that if i stop for 6 months, at least when i come back I dont have to race to grind. I can just pick up where I left off and slowly make my character stronger, permanently. 

TL;DR
Game gud. If want bigger number item, not for you. Like explore, game for you.

I've heard about this game over the years as a casual MMO player but never really played until recently, so far I'm impressed with just the size and scope of the game and how much you can do. The gameplay is great and feels just right and not too World of Warcraft-like if WoW isn't your thing, every race in game has its own personal story that you have (some) shape over which comes up every 10 levels progressed (10, 20, 30 etc.) and adds an insane amount of replay value and options, but it has voice acted scenes so it is a silver lining. Another thing I've noticed was the community for the most part pretty welcoming and helpful if you have any questions. Personally, recommend buying this when it's on sale with just the base game and see if you like it first before fulling jumping in, although if you do, there is a pretty good amount of content to go through. One last thing is that the game respects the amount of time you put into the game, so far I haven't personally seen many instances of micro-transactions unless I actually go and look for it which is nice if you appreciate that. 

All in all I'd say try it out if you want a pretty engaging MMO to sink some time into and just do everything at whatever pace you want without your hand held all the time.

After wandering through various MMORPG for a long time, I finally made my way to Guild Wars 2. And I have to say, it‚Äôs a breath of fresh air, even though the game is over ten years old.

To be honest, I‚Äôm still a complete beginner and haven‚Äôt reached the endgame yet, but my first impressions have been overwhelmingly positive. The most important, and perhaps key difference from other games in the genre is the lack of that frantic gear score race and endless grind. Sure, you won‚Äôt get those unforgettable thrills of being one of the first on the server to clear a dungeon or take down a world boss. But Guild Wars 2 isn‚Äôt about that. This game is about leisurely and thoughtful exploration of a vast, living world, about collecting, about variety. It gives you a sense of immersion in its story and gradually eases you into everything that‚Äôs happening, without unnecessary rush.

What‚Äôs great is that nearly all the content remains relevant, and you can always find people heading to the same places you are. Oh, and the mounts‚ÄîI just have to mention them separately‚Äîthey are implemented on a whole other level.

I haven't played this game for 15 minutes. I've played it for 12 years, actually. And this is the only MMO that I never put down for long enough to not pick it back up again. While it's not true that there was never a day when I haven't played this game, I don't think there was ever a month since its launch. This was and always will be the perfect online game for me, and I keep loving it and the day the servers shut down will be the last day I play a live-service game.

I've got 1100 hours in FFXIV. I thought THAT game was good (admittedly dying), but then I played GW2. My god. Players actually doing quests outside of town and NOT being a ghost world MMO, wayyy better story (imo), and significantly more ways to enjoy the game. Like, I genuinely want to run around and map complete everything because other random players are there doing the same things with me. 

To give you my best memory yet, I was just running around completing a region map when I saw a random portal entrance with NO POI marker, so naturally I ran in and it turned out to be an event quest that involved pitch black jumping puzzles with monsters and traps. You had to essentially hold torches and use them to scare off the shadow monsters while navigating through the puzzle. I decided it was probably a little too much for me but when I went to turn around, another player walked in, and started spam jumping. We then spent 30 min dying to blind pitfall jumps, and after being gored by countless traps and horrifying enemies, we finished the puzzle and killed the dungeon boss. When we left the instance, we both /cheered and went on our separate ways. I felt like I had finally seen the light of what an "social" MMO SHOULD be. That was just ONE instance of the player interaction I've had in GW2 so far. There's so many others.

With over 1,000 hours poured into the world of Tyria, Guild Wars 2 isn't just an MMO‚Äîit's one of my all-time favorite gaming experiences. From the moment I stepped into this vibrant world, I knew I had found a true gaming masterpiece that continually draws me back.

What truly sets GW2 apart is its revolutionary approach to progression. The horizontal progression system is a breath of fresh air; unlike many other MMOs, you never feel like you‚Äôre miles behind the veterans. Once you hit the gear cap, your focus shifts to cosmetic achievements, alternative builds, and mastery points, ensuring that the time invested always feels meaningful, not obsolete. This system lets you truly enjoy the ride rather than rush to max level, though the leveling process itself flows quickly and naturally.

The community is genuinely one of the friendliest I've ever encountered in an online game. Time and again, I've met kind, helpful people who are always eager to assist new or returning players, making every interaction a pleasure. This helpful culture is central to the game's cooperative atmosphere.

Beyond the friendly faces, the game‚Äôs core features are exceptional. I've fallen in love with the compelling story arcs and the sheer joy of traversing the landscape with the game-changing mounts. Even more engaging is the Structured Player vs Player (SPVP) system, which offers an exciting, competitive environment that feels perfectly balanced for quick, intense matches.

For a player like me, who takes regular breaks due to other games and real-life commitments, Guild Wars 2 is the perfect anchor. I always find myself returning, and thanks to the horizontal design, I never feel penalized for the time away. It‚Äôs a beautifully crafted world that respects your time and is a delight to come back to. If you‚Äôre looking for an MMO that‚Äôs competitive, welcoming, and endlessly fun, look no further‚Äîthis is it.

This game sets a new gold standard for MMOs. I cannot bring myself to play any other major MMO because I feel like I've been spoiled with this game. They all just feel outdated by comparison. Even newer ones that have come out after this one. I don't see why they don't copy more from this game. 99.8% server uptime since launch. No server maintenance due to a patch or expansion launch. No kill stealing, everyone gets exp and loot. Horizontal progression, you can new abilities instead of just becoming strong at max level. Evergreen content everywhere, meaning every expansion is still worth buying and playing, none of it is obsolete or can be soloed because you're over-leveled. Open world bosses that bring hundreds of players together. Skill based PvP without worrying about gear. Huge open world full scale warfare like PvP, capturing castles and forts, securing supply lines and cutting off the enemies. NO SUBSCRIPTION! You can stop playing for years and come back right where you left off, no having to grind for new gear! Plus, even though there's a cash shop, you can exchange in-game gold into cash shop currency meaning you can buy these items without spending real world money.

Certainly, the game is not without its faults. The cash shop can be excessive in some areas (the game is not pay to win, just some pay for convenience things like inventory slots or infinite use items). Some balance issues and long waits between major patches. There's a long list of things that I could complain about, but they're smaller compared to how much this game gets right. Most of these complaints are out of love, not hate for this game. I want to see this game succeed.

I have yet to find an MMO that does the Massively Multiplayer better, than Guild Wars 2, and I hope more people will see this game's success and learn from it.

Underrated MMO imo, lots of content, no endless vertical progression or reset or fomo, just hop on and play whenever you want, quit for years come back and not have to regrind for new gear. Game has an extensive cash shop with cosmetic or convience items, but you can buy and earn everything in it for free by trading gold for cash currency, events, and daily/weekly rewards. 
Game can be overwhelming with amount of activies but once you learn everything its rewarding. Its a good as a casual mmo, but also offers stuff for pvpers or raiders, world pvp reminds of planetside 2, skill based arena pvp. Exploring world is fun finding random caves with chests and puzzles. This is probably the best mmo for people who dont have alot of time to play games. i think in the long run, guild wars 2 will outlast most mmos just from the way its designed. Even if they release guild wars 3 eventually, guild wars 1 is still getting support and i imagine guild wars 2 will as well.

Having a blast in this game. Very similar to World of Warcraft but different races and lore. 

I will say, the gameplay is more engaging since there is a dodge roll. I died probably 10-15 in my 100 hours during PvE content. (loads more in PVP!) Dying isn't a big deal usually, just need to respawn at a checkpoint or warp stone nearby, no penalty really. I wouldn't say it's a lot harder than other MMORPGs, but you will need to focus a little more than just spamming auto-attack and standing there like I've experienced in other similar games. 

+The jump puzzles are very fun
+The mounts feel great to ride (they have movement abilities) 
+Good, campy fantasy story that made me look forward to the expansions.
+Level-balanced 5v5 PVP from level 1 of the game! (World.vs.World PvP at level 80 is gear-dependent) 
+Gems (in-game premium currency) can be purchased with Gold (in-game regular currency)
+At 100 hours, I feel like I'm just getting started, with 6 more DLCs of MSQ to play through and lots of fun stuff to unlock. 

MONETIZATION:
A big draw for me is that there are no subscription fees, not even optional ones. Progression feels good and it isn't tied to whether you have an active sub or not, as is the case in many MMORPGs.   

The free-to-play content is pretty big, took me about 50 hours to get through the base game MSQ with one character.

I bought the 2-pack DLC (the Thorns and Fire one) because it unlocks mounts permanently. If you play on the free version, it's going to give you a mount for 10 hours then you have to walk it if you don't get the DLC. There is fast travel and abilities that make you get temporary speed boosts, but the mount is much more efficient and keeps things moving along. 

There is very limited bag space, so you likely eventually want to purchase more inventory slots if you play longer. There is a shared bank tab which is cool. 

All together, the game would cost you about $230 to get all the DLC expansions and "Living Worlds". (*At FULL Price. ~$160 on sale) The Living Worlds are story expansions in between the core Expansions that contain vital info to cover the gaps.  This would be everything you would need to play the past decade of story content and likely thousands of hours across several alts.  

Buying the DLCs will also get you some extra character slots as well. They have also given me 1 level 80 boost for each expansion I purchased, so I now have 1 level 80 main and 3 lvl 80 alts. 

Convenience costs... There are several of these that can definitely be frustrating but not prohibitive. Inventory space is extremely limited if you don't get any of the starter packs in the store. I spent and extra $55 get all three of these (a $10, $25, and $30) These aren't completely necessary but they make my bag and bank space feel much less claustrophobic. It includes a unbreakable tool kit and unlimited salvager that eliminated the annoying chore of resupplying those items. 

SO, $300 total (assuming full price) and I'd say you never need to spend another dollar in the game. This is pretty good imo considering how much there is in it and no subscription fees.

No one ever talks about the monetization of this game. It tries to have it's premium expansion-model cake AND a slice of free-2-play pie at the same time.

"B-buh No Subscription" you probably hear repeated ad-f$$king nauseum. And that's all you ever hear people talk about. No mention of the huge array of pay-for-convenience features in the cash shop, like infinite gathering tools, bank and inventory and crafting ingredient inventory expansions, etc, etc...

And especially no one ever mentions the Living World Seasons, which any other MMO would include under the patches for a given expansion. You'll note that they're not shown for sale here on steam. Nah, you have to get 100hrs deep and hit level 80 before you realize that to continue the story in the proper order that it was told, your expansion/DLC purchases mean nothing, shell out for the individual season as a separate $$$ purchase. Or you could skip it and miss out on swathes of content as well as story.

Apparently the LW seasons were given for free to people who were there when they released, which I'm sure was nice if you didn't Miss Out. Funny how people say this game has no FOMO.

[h2]= Wasted Potential =[/h2]

[b](Note; My total playtime across Steam and the ANet launcher is somewhere between 3,000-4,000 hours.)[/b] 

This game is a very mixed bag; There‚Äôs a lot that GW2 does well, some that it does very poorly, and most that it doesn‚Äôt do anywhere near as well as it should.

I‚Äôd like to delve deeply into each topic, but due to Steam‚Äôs odd character limit, I‚Äôll have to condense some 60 pages of thoughts into just a couple.

Let‚Äôs get into the list:

[h3]The Good;[/h3]
[b]+ Amount of Content[/b] - There‚Äôs a lot of it, even if you don‚Äôt buy any of the expansions. Months to years worth.
[b]+ Sense of Progression[/b] - In most MMORPGs the sense of progression comes from your character becoming stronger, meaning that you‚Äôre essentially watching numbers go up. In GW2, progression takes place mainly through the unlocking of masteries, which open up functions, abilities, movement types etc. Everything from a gryphon doing its best impression of a F-16 fighter jet, to a beetle that really wishes it could be in a Need For Speed game - masteries unlock some truly awesome stuff that simply change how you play the game.
[b]+ Aesthetics[/b] - Everything from the gear you wear, to the architectures of the different cultures, is very well-designed. This doesn‚Äôt mean that there are no occasional oddities, but the vast majority of the time, things look great.
[b]+ Audio[/b] - The OST is awesome, the voice work (audio quality-wise) is stellar and the SFX is likewise great.
[b]+ Quality of Life Features[/b] - You can save builds for your characters, as well as gear loadouts to match them. Auto-sort for better inventory management. Shared bank space. Account-wide masteries. Account-wide friend/block-lists. On and on the list goes.
[b]+ UI[/b] - It has a few issues, granted, which mainly pertain to the low visibility of some procs - but outside of minor stuff like that? The UI is perfectly fine. GW2‚Äôs UI does not  require any significant fixing on the player‚Äôs behalf, unlike some other MMOs I could mention.
[b]+ Meta Events[/b] - These are a lot of fun and, by far, the best in the genre. Not that there is much competition out there.
[b]+ World vs World[/b] - This is a ‚Äúopen-world‚Äù-ish PvP mode, where three factions duke it out on large open maps. This mode is by far the best PvP I have experienced since the Hillsbrad Foothills era of Vanilla WoW. I‚Äôve spent months doing nothing but playing WvW endlessly, day after day. And I‚Äôm not even a PvPer at heart. 

[h3]The Bad;[/h3]
[b]- Writing[/b] - It‚Äôs positively fucking atrocious. Several magnitudes worse than ‚Äúdecent‚Äù. From character motivations, to the lore presented to you, to the voiced dialogue - Almost all of it sits somewhere between insufferable, illogical, brain-dead and annoying. Why people do what they do makes no sense, why you‚Äôre told to do what you‚Äôre doing makes no sense, why most of the situations in the game even arise to begin with makes no sense. Even your character - the Commander - makes no sense; You give no commands, have no say in the decision-making, or strategy, or tactics of any given scenario. Exceptions? Few and far between. You‚Äôre not playing a commander - You‚Äôre playing a slave. Put simply; This is a game that waterboards you with nonsense as a reward for caring to read and listen to what it has to say.
[b]- Story[/b] - The Personal Story (Base Game) part of the story is tolerable. Not great, but tolerable. That stuff is from 2012. So, as you play through it, you‚Äôll think to yourself; ‚ÄúWow, this is pretty good for something that's 13 years old! All the newer stuff must be even better!‚Äù Dead wrong. Post base game, GW2 has - by far - the worst story I have ever had to play through. Worse than FFXIV, ESO, and even WoW. The story content of GW2‚Äôs expansions should be classified as cruel and unusual punishment by the UN, forced upon only the most evil of human beings as a form of torture. Every hour you spend playing through this absolute garbage, you‚Äôll feel like the game hates you for playing it, hates you for having bought it, hates you for even bothering to pay attention to it. It‚Äôs painful to such a degree that I ended up having to take week-long breaks from it, before I could stomach doing another chapter.
[b]- Community[/b] - People will tell you that GW2 has one of the nicest communities in the MMO genre. What they won‚Äôt tell you, is that most of the time said ‚Äúniceness‚Äù is fake, that honesty is scarce, that the overwhelming majority of the people in this game can‚Äôt handle criticism and thus are either unable or unwilling to improve. Most Meta Event leaders are on some kind of a power trip, most serious WvW squad leaders are paranoid Discord cultists, and most of the playerbase in general consists of remarkably fragile people. It‚Äôs a very strange sort of ecosystem.
[b]- Combat[/b] - The targeting is weird beyond belief, no matter how you customize it. Several builds rely on procs/buffs that you can barely see or pay attention to, mid-combat. Content, story or otherwise, is designed to ensure that one of two states is almost always true; Either you are crowd controlled/debuffed, or; Things go invulnerable/teleport out of reach. Skills can have very strange hitboxes at times, especially in situations where the Y axis is involved. In short; Combat, in this game, feels like an inconvenience designed to piss you off at nearly every turn.

[h3]The Ugly Conclusion;[/h3]
GW2 is simultaneously the MMO that has impressed me more than any other, while also being the greatest disappointment I‚Äôve ever experienced in this genre.

The core issue is that the things that GW2 fails to do well, makes no sense for it to fail at. There‚Äôs no reason why the story has to be written like trash, year after year. There‚Äôs no reason why targeting has to remain an illogical mess. There‚Äôs no reason for why characters must be insufferable and annoying. There are no good reasons that I can think of, even in an abstract hypothetical, for why these things must necessarily be of such low quality.

Whereas the 13 years after its release should have seen GW2 steadily improve at everything that it does, this has not been the case; Some things have been improved (QoL, Masteries, Specs), some things have gotten worse (Writing, Story, Wold Building), and some have been flat out neglected and ignored (Threads filled with people asking for fixes to technical issues that have gone ignored for over a decade).

GW2 is a mess - A statement that applies to pretty much every MMO out there, yes, but one that has never been so bitter a thing to say about an MMO until GW2.

I'd ([i]generously[/i]) rate this game a 5.5/10 - A solid 7/10 when it's at its best, and an abysmal 3/10 when it's at it's worst. A tremendous waste of exceptional potential.

If Steam ever increases the character limit tenfold, I‚Äôll be more than happy to come back here and add the dozens - if not hundreds - of details that these topics, good and bad, deserve.

So let me start by saying I would recommend this game despite giving it a thumbs down. I'm only giving it a thumbs down cause I would not recommend buying it through STEAM. I played Guild Wars 2 years ago, and decided to pick it up again when I realized it was added to STEAM. I was excited when I realized I could use my old account. However, I realized that is a huge problem when it came to buying the DLCs. I bought the Path of Fire and Heart of Thorns bundle. Eager to experience new parts of the game since I hadn't ever played any of the DLCs before. However, if you are playing Guild Wars 2 through steam with an account you originally made through Arenanet, yet buy the DLCs through STEAM they you will be screwed. You will not be able to access the content. You need to buy the DLCs through Arenanet to be able to play them. STEAM will not refund it for me cause I have played the game more than 2 hours. I had made a new character, and so obviously I didn't get to the point where I would experience the new content within two hours before I realized this mistake. I had to buy the DLC AGAIN through Arenanet to play it. So for those who come after me, if you are playing with an old Arenanet account but playing on STEAM. DO NOT BUY DLCS ON STEAM FOR THIS GAME, YOU WILL GET SCREWED.

I played on the ANet launcher.

I enjoyed certain aspects of the game like the world itself, jumping puzzles, and all the mounts. I found the combat, story, pvp, recent expac content, and instanced content bad or mediocre. No one really talks about the QoL problem that ANet has created here though, and it's what ultimately made me shelf GW2.

Why do I only get 5 character slots after spending $180 dollars on all the expansions and living world seasons? I can't even make one character per class with that, as there's 9 classes in the game. GW2 is constantly throwing hundreds of crafting materials, event items, and random trash at you, so why is my inventory, material storage, and bank space so Infinitesimally small? 

So they can annoy you into spending money in the cash shop.

Bag slots, bank slots, extra material storage, shared inventory slots, mistlock pass, reusable salvage machines, reusable teleport devices, unbreakable gathering tools, account services, boosters, build templates, lootboxes, mountains of cosmetics (with way more effort put into them than the free cosmetics), and more, are all available on rotation in the FOMO inducing cash shop. A lot of this stuff is only bound to the character you bought it on, btw.

YES you can buy these items by converting ingame gold into gems, though working at McDonald's and swiping your card to buy gems is going to be 1000% more time efficient. Spending your $1 an hour amount of gold you farmed on the cash shop means that you're going to hinder your legendary weapon progress just so you can buy QoL. GW2's endgame made me feel like my ultimate goal was just grinding gold to get account features, which isn't what I want to be working towards in an MMO. It's all a gold sink.

Look, PvP in this game is beyond trash.
Compared to WoW:
1. Instead of class-specific buffs, debuffs, there are so-called "boons" and "conditions" - the same across all classes! You have no clue who, what, when cast.
2. Awful UI. Few-to-none settings. Names, nameplates are small and color palette is poor. You take time to understand what even your target is - Is it a player, a downed player, a pet or even a mob - Is it a player you want to target or one that is behind?! You click on an enemy player and you aren't even sure what the hell you just selected.
3. No mods to replace this garbage.
4. WvW, compared to WoW's BG, is a mount simulator. There are no cemetries and you have to run across whole massive battleground again. The more ground you gain, the more time you waste on travel in case of death.
5. Weapon swap and different stances are pain because there is no way to see what abilities are ready. You only see abilities for your current weapon or stance.
6. Turning circle of a mount - An in-game horse simulator. What a brilliant idea!
7. Action bars are laggy. Sometimes when casting a sequence of spells, it turns out that some spells haven't been used.
8. Unlocking talent (skill) tree requires you to complete Hero challenges. They are easy but scattered all over the game map and aren't account-wide. Each time you create a new hero, you have to visit them all again. It is a microtransaction bait as they sell them in the store.

I have 2,000 hours on their official launcher, not on steam. The positives are combat (the best of all mmos), pve content (mainly open-world), and transmutations/cosplay stuff.

Anyways this game is quite bad and frustrates me with the amount of potential it wastes at every turn. The multiple problems this game has include:

- A lot of content is fine but all of it is just farming simulators and becomes boring real quick. You eventually stop caring about the content and just want gold to buy more shit like gems to buy store items (some of which are really god damn stupid like build templates that aren't account wide, just for that character), shit to make more money, gen 1 legendaries, etc. It ends up feeling like you are making money to EVENTUALLY have fun...

- Gem store prices are garbage (sales make it not as bad but still). $5 for 400 gems, with 500 being for that specific character's equipment template meaning you have to buy 100 more gems/exchange gold for gems JUST FOR 1 template. Also build templates, inventory slot increase as well (inventory can be increased like with the quickplay fractal event) and character slot which cost 800 gems. You can farm gold into gems, but you will burn yourself out/get bored on gold farming methods.

- Gem store prices for cosmetics/skins is not only bad, they are also time-gated, meaning you have to wait months to a year for them to reappear. Also something I hate is armor being sold as a set. If I want a hat from a set, you have to buy the whole thing. It sucks when I'm trying to make my own sets.

- Half-baked and abandoned content. Dragon response missions, pvp and ESPECIALLY wvw are abandoned. WvW is one of their best and most unique gamemodes, and yet they have done NOTHING with it for more than a decade. And when they did add to WvW like world restructuring and nerfs (while leaving stealth untouched and completely cancerous), it did not help the gamemode and even made it worse in some regards.

- Continuing with WvW, you have toxic players and guilds running around making the game unenjoyable, insufferable professions/elite specs, Bm asshats, griefers/trolls, garbage mechanics (defending is completely worthless/pointless), god damn spawn camping, etc. Players have asked for changes for a decade and the devs ignore it... 

- Community is fairly toxic, though early game it's good. Part of it is due to timed events, sweaty tryhards and devs that don't give a shit about scummy players/guilds (which is why in-game reporting does nothing. Tickets seems to do more? But still). Expect drama, politics, trash-talking/bm, toxicity, weirdos, trolling, etc.

- Not being able to move skills around. You can bind keys/buttons, but not skills. For example on Gun warrior, the 4 skill evades backward. I despise it and wish I could place it on 5 WITHOUT screwing up my other skills with other weapons.

More minor problems include: 

- Bugs that range from funny (animation glitches) to annoying (builds not switching during wvw, having to use a skill to get out of combat, texture glitches)

- Story, characters and voice acting. Sometimes it's ok/good (not great), other times it's complete garbage. Drizzlewood for example has god awful voice acting/direction, and Secrets of the obscure's story is just weird and bad (mainly the 2nd half). The rest I'm not invested in/don't care.

- Characters are kind of ugly/lack choices (unless you use gems and even then the selection isn't great). And weird proportions like male Norns being freaks, or human legs are scrawny even when you choose a bulky look.

- Maps can be frustrating like enemy placements/enemy attacks. PoF expansion has enemies that will knock you off your mount a lot, HoT has high damage enemies, etc.

- Wiki. All of it. Event timers, where to get items, how to get to different areas/maps, explaining wvw, etc.

- Item variety. Only a few modern caps/hats, pants being based on specs (light has cloth-based leggings, medium being just tight pants, heavy has mostly plated skirts), the selection is so bad even with so many damn armor pieces.

Overall there are just so many problems that you will feel after awhile. And WvW absolutely pisses me off and showed me the devs don't really care about the game outside of pve, which is boring at times. They throw so many ideas at the game then drop them immediately. It frustrates me as it could be so good/the best but it does everything it can to ruin itself. 


At least it's f2p/doesn't have a subscription so if you are on the fence about it you can play it. But man it has so much garbage aspects that start to wear down my enjoyment of the game. Devs do better god damn it

Combat with elite specs is too much busy work that lacks intuitiveness.  

Way too many currencies and varying types of vendors.  Quite confusing.

Crafting is pointless and expensive.   There seems to be no rewards for doing such a laborious activity.  Might be the worst crafting I have experienced in these types of games since you don't use anything you make unless you have maxed out the profession.  (which will likely take real money to convert gems into gold to do so)  (it's also much cheaper to just buy the same items with gold than it is to actually craft them...which is weird)

Overall atmosphere of the game is great.  Some elements seem fun and original.

PROS:

- The game is kinda fun when you hit level 10 and get a free mount trial, although it's short-lived since it's taken away 10 hours later and you're hit with "Spend $25.99 on an expansion to continue riding your mount.", so I guess this is technically not a pro.

CONS:

- Saying the customer support is F tier is an understatement.
- Constant barrage of microtransactions at every turn.
- Uses all the popular manipulative tactics like FOMO and pay-for-convenience traps.
- Several features are broken, abandoned, or unfinished.

[h2]= Wasted Potential =[/h2]

[b](Note; My total playtime across Steam and the ANet launcher is somewhere between 3,000-4,000 hours.)[/b] 

This game is a very mixed bag; There‚Äôs a lot that GW2 does well, some that it does very poorly, and most that it doesn‚Äôt do anywhere near as well as it should.

I‚Äôd like to delve deeply into each topic, but due to Steam‚Äôs odd character limit, I‚Äôll have to condense some 60 pages of thoughts into just a couple.

Let‚Äôs get into the list:

[h3]The Good;[/h3]
[b]+ Amount of Content[/b] - There‚Äôs a lot of it, even if you don‚Äôt buy any of the expansions. Months to years worth.
[b]+ Sense of Progression[/b] - In most MMORPGs the sense of progression comes from your character becoming stronger, meaning that you‚Äôre essentially watching numbers go up. In GW2, progression takes place mainly through the unlocking of masteries, which open up functions, abilities, movement types etc. Everything from a gryphon doing its best impression of a F-16 fighter jet, to a beetle that really wishes it could be in a Need For Speed game - masteries unlock some truly awesome stuff that simply change how you play the game.
[b]+ Aesthetics[/b] - Everything from the gear you wear, to the architectures of the different cultures, is very well-designed. This doesn‚Äôt mean that there are no occasional oddities, but the vast majority of the time, things look great.
[b]+ Audio[/b] - The OST is awesome, the voice work (audio quality-wise) is stellar and the SFX is likewise great.
[b]+ Quality of Life Features[/b] - You can save builds for your characters, as well as gear loadouts to match them. Auto-sort for better inventory management. Shared bank space. Account-wide masteries. Account-wide friend/block-lists. On and on the list goes.
[b]+ UI[/b] - It has a few issues, granted, which mainly pertain to the low visibility of some procs - but outside of minor stuff like that? The UI is perfectly fine. GW2‚Äôs UI does not  require any significant fixing on the player‚Äôs behalf, unlike some other MMOs I could mention.
[b]+ Meta Events[/b] - These are a lot of fun and, by far, the best in the genre. Not that there is much competition out there.
[b]+ World vs World[/b] - This is a ‚Äúopen-world‚Äù-ish PvP mode, where three factions duke it out on large open maps. This mode is by far the best PvP I have experienced since the Hillsbrad Foothills era of Vanilla WoW. I‚Äôve spent months doing nothing but playing WvW endlessly, day after day. And I‚Äôm not even a PvPer at heart. 

[h3]The Bad;[/h3]
[b]- Writing[/b] - It‚Äôs positively fucking atrocious. Several magnitudes worse than ‚Äúdecent‚Äù. From character motivations, to the lore presented to you, to the voiced dialogue - Almost all of it sits somewhere between insufferable, illogical, brain-dead and annoying. Why people do what they do makes no sense, why you‚Äôre told to do what you‚Äôre doing makes no sense, why most of the situations in the game even arise to begin with makes no sense. Even your character - the Commander - makes no sense; You give no commands, have no say in the decision-making, or strategy, or tactics of any given scenario. Exceptions? Few and far between. You‚Äôre not playing a commander - You‚Äôre playing a slave. Put simply; This is a game that waterboards you with nonsense as a reward for caring to read and listen to what it has to say.
[b]- Story[/b] - The Personal Story (Base Game) part of the story is tolerable. Not great, but tolerable. That stuff is from 2012. So, as you play through it, you‚Äôll think to yourself; ‚ÄúWow, this is pretty good for something that's 13 years old! All the newer stuff must be even better!‚Äù Dead wrong. Post base game, GW2 has - by far - the worst story I have ever had to play through. Worse than FFXIV, ESO, and even WoW. The story content of GW2‚Äôs expansions should be classified as cruel and unusual punishment by the UN, forced upon only the most evil of human beings as a form of torture. Every hour you spend playing through this absolute garbage, you‚Äôll feel like the game hates you for playing it, hates you for having bought it, hates you for even bothering to pay attention to it. It‚Äôs painful to such a degree that I ended up having to take week-long breaks from it, before I could stomach doing another chapter.
[b]- Community[/b] - People will tell you that GW2 has one of the nicest communities in the MMO genre. What they won‚Äôt tell you, is that most of the time said ‚Äúniceness‚Äù is fake, that honesty is scarce, that the overwhelming majority of the people in this game can‚Äôt handle criticism and thus are either unable or unwilling to improve. Most Meta Event leaders are on some kind of a power trip, most serious WvW squad leaders are paranoid Discord cultists, and most of the playerbase in general consists of remarkably fragile people. It‚Äôs a very strange sort of ecosystem.
[b]- Combat[/b] - The targeting is weird beyond belief, no matter how you customize it. Several builds rely on procs/buffs that you can barely see or pay attention to, mid-combat. Content, story or otherwise, is designed to ensure that one of two states is almost always true; Either you are crowd controlled/debuffed, or; Things go invulnerable/teleport out of reach. Skills can have very strange hitboxes at times, especially in situations where the Y axis is involved. In short; Combat, in this game, feels like an inconvenience designed to piss you off at nearly every turn.

[h3]The Ugly Conclusion;[/h3]
GW2 is simultaneously the MMO that has impressed me more than any other, while also being the greatest disappointment I‚Äôve ever experienced in this genre.

The core issue is that the things that GW2 fails to do well, makes no sense for it to fail at. There‚Äôs no reason why the story has to be written like trash, year after year. There‚Äôs no reason why targeting has to remain an illogical mess. There‚Äôs no reason for why characters must be insufferable and annoying. There are no good reasons that I can think of, even in an abstract hypothetical, for why these things must necessarily be of such low quality.

Whereas the 13 years after its release should have seen GW2 steadily improve at everything that it does, this has not been the case; Some things have been improved (QoL, Masteries, Specs), some things have gotten worse (Writing, Story, Wold Building), and some have been flat out neglected and ignored (Threads filled with people asking for fixes to technical issues that have gone ignored for over a decade).

GW2 is a mess - A statement that applies to pretty much every MMO out there, yes, but one that has never been so bitter a thing to say about an MMO until GW2.

I'd ([i]generously[/i]) rate this game a 5.5/10 - A solid 7/10 when it's at its best, and an abysmal 3/10 when it's at it's worst. A tremendous waste of exceptional potential.

If Steam ever increases the character limit tenfold, I‚Äôll be more than happy to come back here and add the dozens - if not hundreds - of details that these topics, good and bad, deserve.
